* Even in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> which I visited over a year ago I found a tremendous dearth of technical training and of equipment in technical schools and colleges. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* If it happens in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> it happens even more so in Asian countries, as I found out from visiting them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I want to speak about a matter which I believe is of paramount importance to Australia and that is our relationship with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Before very long we will be moving to a situation of self-government in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I think this is a tribute to the far-sighted, statesmanlike policies of the Leader of the Opposition  (Mr Whitlam)  following upon his very much publicised, and at the time criticised, visit to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> 21 years ago. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* 1 also think that if the present Prime Minister  (Mr McMahon)  had been Prime Minister any earlier we may not have reached the situation in which we are today, because I think that the right honourable member for Higgins  (Mr Gorton)  was probably pushed by the Leader of the Opposition into coming out in favour- of early selfgovernment and independence - for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I would like to say something about the military relationship of Australia with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I think this matter is of paramount importance because <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is our closest neighbour, because shortly, as I have said, it will achieve self-government and independence, because that independent country may have to face enormous economic and political problems and last but not least, because there are many Australian nationals who will be involved in any changeover that takes place. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* The first is the forthcoming selfgovernment and what I call the present de facto self-government in " <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* The second is the existence of a number of separatist movements within <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> itself. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* When I was in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> during the last recess I detected, I think, some feeling that the Government was being a little bit indecisive on some things. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* However, no matter how politically adroit the Government might be we cannot close our eyes to the possibility of a secessionist movement being in conflict with the government of an independent <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* It is far from impossible that in such a situation the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> would want to use its army. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I appreciate that finding the answers is not easy, but whatever happens, if something goes wrong in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Australia rightly or wrongly will get some of the blame for it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* We must still make a maximum effort to see that there is no interference by Australia in the internal affairs of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> after independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Very shortly moves must be made to pass the responsibility for the Pacific Islands Regiment over to the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* We have to make it clear that this will not happen in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* We do not want Australia to have a garrison in Singapore and we do not want an Australian garrison in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* The Pacific Islands Regiment should be brought under the responsibility of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I believe that Australia's military presence in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> should be redesigned so that the force becomes fundamentally an indigenous force. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Our servicemen should be supernumeraries and should act only to the extent requested by the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I appreciate that many of these questions must be dealt with very carefully but our military relationship with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> must be squarely faced and on this subject we cannot afford to bury our heads in the sand. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* If we do less, we will be doing a disservice not only to ourselves but also to the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* In the short time left to me I would like to say that I think a very much greater commitment for civil aid to be given to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> after independence should be stated by the Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I am sure that much of the opposition to independence within <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has sprung from a fear amongst the people of that country that if it is given independence Australia will up stumps and leave Papua [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Many Australian public servants in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> feel that they are being let down by the Government and I would like to see a greater measure of support for them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Australian who is working in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I hope that this situation will be rectified and that the Australian Government will state quite clearly that it will give continuing civil support to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> as long as that country wants to keep Australian personnel. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* 8 presented by the Treasurer  (Mr Snedden)  on 15th August shows a proposed expenditure of $220m in 1972-73 on official economic aid to developing countries, including $145m for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* With the exception of a loan in ,<span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> our aid has been given, as grant aid with no strings 'attached. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* In 1972-73, in addition to further .financial assistance for the building of the defence forces in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, the Government proposes to spend approximately $14m on defence aid to certain developing countries in South East Asia. * I think that if the Minister were fair, and if this were not an election year he in turn would pay tribute to the Leader of the Opposition for the wonderful job he did in January 1970 when he visited <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Indeed, any objective observer would realise that the visit by the Leader of the Opposition created the catalyst through which all the splendid developments that we now see taking place in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> have come. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* The change came with the new Minister and it is very stimulating for those of us who have been able to visit that country to see what has happened in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* Let me make it clear to the Committee that at the moment about $2Sm of the Australian taxpayers' money is being spent on the defence resources in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I am not going to pass judgment on whether this is a correct sum and I am not going to pass judgment on how this money is being spent in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> other than to say that it is my belief that it should be spent through the Department of External Territories and not directly through an appropriation to the Department of the Army. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* J feel it would then be clearer that it would be the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government itself -  Mr Michael  Somare and his Cabinet - which would decide whether this money should be spent on defence. * But the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> may prefer to spend some of it in another way, or it may consider that it needs more defence and spend more of the appropriation going through the Department of External Territories on defence. * I believe that we have made a mistake in foisting on to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> a similarly sophisticated Public Service establishment. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I believe that the first step has now been taken to see that the Public Service establishment in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is not so sophisticated or expensive. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* He talked about the situation in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and brought to our attention some of the very real changes which will occur in this area of our immediate environment. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I believe that the aid we have been giving to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been of great assistance. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* It is very important that this matter be given serious consideration and that we do not build up an elite in the Pacific Islands Regiment to the detriment of other areas of activity in the Territory of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. * The increase in aid in this budgetary year to $220m, including the major portion that goes to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, is one of the more commendable developments in our budgeting this year. * I think that our good will, our interest and our money will be needed for as long as we possibly can expend them in that quarter, because the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> face problems which are, I think, a good deal more serious than the would-be urban crises which are developed by our friends from the Australian Labor Party in respect to Australia. * Another is the na?r of appropriating $40m, which at the moment goes directly from Austraia  to  <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> under, I believe, the estimates of the Prime Minister's Department or maybe some other department rather than through the Department of External Territories. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* This amount is being spent on the extra salaries of Australians working in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I want to add to those  2  areas of difference by pointing out that I hope that an Australian Labor Party government will give the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> - the Administrator's Executive Council as the Cabinet of that country is known now  -  n:n idea of what the long term financial commitments of this country will be. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I am referring to the Office of Programming and Co-ordination, which is one of the departments of government in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, The Office of Programming and Co-ordination was not brought to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> because of some clear thinking on the part of Australian politicians. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* We ail realise that a tremendous amount of the aid from Australia does go to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I believe that we may be able to do this in the not too distant future because of the extra income that will accrue to the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> from the Bougainville project. * These are part of the calculations which would be made when we in Australia decide on some formula in relation to what amount we will appropriate to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> over the long term. * <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s first Chief Minister,  Mr Somare,  sees this country's future linked with Japan and Asia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* I repeat that I do not feel at all resentful about Japan's taking an increasing interest in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* The more people who trade with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and take its products, the better. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#debate-36)

* How many persons are employed by the Department of Transport of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#subdebate-38-20)

* The <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Public -Service  is  arranged into three divisions as follows: [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721010_reps_27_hor81/#subdebate-38-20)

* Yes, like <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, for example. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1972/19721011_reps_27_hor81/#subdebate-31-0)

* The changes were made very satisfactorily in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> after the visit to that part of the world by the right honourable member for Higgins  (Mr Gorton)  when he was Prime Minister. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I assume the now normal practice has occurred and that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has made the choice of currencies and that we have endorsed it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Under the transferred power this after all is <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s right. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* 1  am delighted that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has received the assurances of the Prime Minister  (Mr Whitlam)  regarding long term aid to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Some of the questions to be answered include the extent to which financial aid should be fully on a project basis or whether, as is the case now, some of it should be devoted to supporting an annual or multi-annual program of expenditure; whether there should continue to be an oversight of project aid; whether <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> projects will continue to have preferential access to the Australian market; and. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* as mentioned tonight, whether Commonwealth assistance by way of guarantee of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s international loans and through encouragement of investment will continue. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Other countries may well wish to direct some portion of their overseas aid towards <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* On this matter I assume that the attitude of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> would depend on many factors which it would weigh up at the appropriate time. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* But, speaking personally, I see no reason why <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> should not welcome assistance from other donors. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* There may even be occasions when Australia and another country undertake to assist a <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> project together. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Certainly some of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s natural resources have such a potential that their development might best be financed by such an arrangement. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* However, the prime motivating factor is naturally the attitude of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Therefore, it is not impossible to imagine such an arrangement being made with an independent <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Australia is now withdrawing from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Although we will continue to assist, increasingly the brunt of decision making will be with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s own leaders - and so it should be. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The present Government in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has shown how capably it can administer its affairs. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* There can be no doubt that the next few years are the most important to the future of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I believe that, above all countries with which we are associated, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> needs special consideration as it moves through selfgovernment, independence and beyond. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* It goes back some years originally to the missions sent by the International Bank which at that time recommended particularly the building of a road from the coast at Lae up to Goroka to open up the inner highland region which contains about one-half of the population of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The resulting economic expansion which should follow from the opening up and improvement of these 2 highways should make a very marked difference to the economy of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> entered the Asian Development Bank in 1971. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* So far no-one has mentioned the importance from the point of view of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> of its being admitted and becoming ah independent member of that organisation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The Asian Development Bank, apart from its importance to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and apart from' <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s importance to us, has a very direct importance to Australia's interests and participation in the South East Asian area. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* So finance and help of this kind from the Asian Development Bank has a value to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in its own right and in the Bank's own right, which is helpful from everybody's point of view. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* House to the developments in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and also to such international institutions as the Asian Development Bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* This is the second loan negotiated by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I stress, in response to a query by the honourable member for Kooyong  (Mr Peacock),  that it is on behalf of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government that these loans are negotiated. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Of course we had to provide guarantees, and the Australian Government has indicated that it will provide guarantees for all loans entered into on behalf of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> through to independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The Asian Development Bank, as honourable members opposite have pointed out, is one of 4 international bodies of which <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has become a member. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> became a member of the Asian Development Bank back in 1971. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I think this is important because what the previous Administration did under the honourable member for Kooyong, who was a Minister, and what we are doing now is to provide an international identity for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Each decision that we are now making in terms of self-government is being looked at from the point of view of the impact that it will have on <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in terms of independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* By the time we come to self-government, which the previous Government decided would be granted on 1st December 1973 and which we fully supported, and before <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> gains independence it will in fact have an international identity. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We regard this as a very important manifestation of our policy towards <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The legislation we are discussing tonight relates to a loan for the construction of a high way in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* As all honourable members will understand, particularly those who have been to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, it is highly important for the development of the country that access to the very remote areas in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> should be made easily available. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The advantage that flows from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> being involved in loans from other organisations, particularly the multilateral organisations, is that it does supplement Australian aid. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* Nobody could say that Australia can provide the totality of the aid that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will need in the future. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We consider - I think I can speak here on behalf of the Opposition too -that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia have a special relationship. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We would not want to stand in the way - moreover, we would not want to be seen to stand in the way - of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> receiving aid from other countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The Prime Minister  (Mr Whitlam)  during his recent visit to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> indicated that we will undertake a 3-year program starting in the budget period of 1974-75. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We regard this as important because <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will need to have certain conditions that are known to it so that it can structure its own budgeting arrangements. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I think it is important that the budgeting processes in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> be revised. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* It was not very long ago that the Permanent Head of the Department of Finance in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> - the Treasurer - indicated that the budgeting arrangements in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> were 50 years out of date. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I am glad that he as the officer responsible there said that because it was a thought that struck me over the years in discussions we have had in this House on the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> budget. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* As <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> approaches self-government and independence it is very necessary that the structuring of the budget - the budgetary practices - in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> be changed. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I think this is important because if <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is to attract aid from other countries, it should have a development budget - in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> it is called, in general terms, an improvement budget - so that foreign countries can attach themselves to projects that are thrown up in the improvement program. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The Government will attach itself to this notion, but because Australia has had a very long association with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> it will not be in strict and inflexible terms. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We will be looking towards an improvement or development budget and a change in the budgetary systems in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and we will be looking towards a definition in the Budget of projects that will open the way for assistance from the developing countries in aid to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* In essence the question was why the present Australian Government was forcing <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to borrow its loan funds from overseas and limiting Australia's contribution to a 'miserly' $10m. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The point is that the Government is not forcing <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> into world loan markets in preference to assistance from the Australian Government, but I think it is important for all honourable members to realise that there are advantages for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in seeking loans from overseas to finance part of its expenditure. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* In the first instance these supplement Australian aid and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> revenue and increase the financial resources available to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* The second point is that it is important for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to establish itself on the world loan market. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* If we leave it much longer <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will have difficulties in entering the international loan market if it cannot provide the sort of guarantees that Australia can provide. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I think <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will build up its credit worthiness as a borrower through this process. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* I apologise to him for the irrelevance, perhaps, of my answer to him, but I think it is very important that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> now entering into the international loan market and becoming an international identity is to be recognised in the international loan market. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* We regard this as one of the important objectives in bringing <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to independence smoothly. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730410_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-14-0)

* An apparent technical deficiency in the provisions governing the taxing of dividends is being remedied by the Bill so that an exempting provision clearly applies in respect of dividends out of profits from gold mining, but not other types of mining, in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730411_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-13-0)

* Additional appropriations amounting to $4 1.4m required for departmental other services include $0.7m for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; $8.6m for the Department of Education of which $5m has been provided for Commonwealth scholarship schemes to cover increases in university fees and the extension of the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme to all children of Aboriginal descent attending secondary schools and classes from the beginning of 1973; $2.5m for education services in the Australian Capital Territory and $0.7m for educational services in the Northern Territory; $3m for the Department of External Territories to cover special assistance to facilitate the transfer of functions to the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Administration, emergency assistance to alleviate food shortages in the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> highlands and salary increases for overseas officers of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Public Service; $5.9m for Colombo Plan and other aid; $2.8m for broadcasting and television services; $1.2m for the final payment of compensation to sulphuric acid and pyrites producers following the termination of bounty payments; $11. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730411_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-17-0)

* Fifth, Australia has a very special responsibility for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> which will soon be self-governing and independent. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* It is important, therefore, that Australia should leave <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> with industrial laws which accord with international standards. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* There are several conventions of particular significance for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> which can only be extended to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and our other non-metropolitan territories when they have been ratified in respect of Australia itself. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* The ratification of ILO conventions has also been discussed with the States - at ministerial level at the meeting of Commonwealth and State Labour Ministers in February and at permanent head level at the meeting of the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee held in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> last week. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* Thus the Government is consulting with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to clear up outstanding action required in respect of ILO conventions ratified by Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* For the first time a tripartite observer delegation from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be attending this year's session of the International Labour Conference and I anticipate that in company with the Minister for Labour of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and the other members of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> delegation I shall be able to register with the Director-General of the International Labour Office a considerable number of declarations on ILO conventions for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730412_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-40-0)

* For the first time there, 7 Commonwealth countries were represented by their heads of government, as were the 2 countries with observer status, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Niue. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730501_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-26-0)

* This Bill seeks the approval of Parliament to the provision of a contractual guarantee by the Australian Government for an overseas borrowing by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in foreign currencies not exceeding the equivalent of- $US20m or $A14.3m. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The proceeds of the loan will be used by the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to finance public works and services. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* Legislation to authorise the borrowing has already been passed by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> House of Assembly. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The borrowing will be the first loan raised by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> on international capital markets, although this is not the first time Parliament has been asked to approve the provision of contractual guarantees for overseas borrowings by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* Parliament has on a number of previous occasions approved such guarantees by the Australiangovernment in respect of loans to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Asian Development Bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* All borrowings by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> internally or on the Australian Market, of course carry a statutory guarantee by the Australian Government by virtue of section 75a of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Act. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* One of the loan possibilities currently being investigated by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government is a public bond issue denominated in Deutschemarks. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* There would, therefore, be insufficient time to seek parliamentary approval for the guarantee after the loan agreement has been signed, as has been the normal practice with guarantees for loans to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Asian Development Bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The form of guarantee that is customarily required in International capital markets is similar to those that have been given to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and to the Asian Development Bank in respect of borrowings by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> from those institutions. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The Bill is purposely couched in general terms in respect of the currency and the precise form of the proposed borrowing so as not to restrict <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s choice as to the particular overseas market in which it finally decided to arrange the loan. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* In present circumstances, it seems probable that the cost of an overseas borrowing by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will not differ greatly from the cost of a borrowing for a comparable term from institutional sources in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government wishes to undertake an overseas borrowing as soon as possible in order that it may establish a favourable standing in international capital markets before it becomes independent, as this could enhance its borrowing prospects thereafter. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* A contractual guarantee by the Australian Government for such a borrowing should ensure the success of this first issue and will materially assist <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in furthering this longer term objective. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-32-0)

* The 1971 Agreement, which was signed on 18th May 1971, delimits the seabed between Australia and Indonesia in the Arafura Sea and between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Indonesia off the southern and northern coasts of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-36-0)

* The boundaries relating to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> were approved in 1971 by the Administrator's Executive Council. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-36-0)

* The 1973 Agreement, which was signed on 12th February 1973 by the Chief Minister of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>,  Mr Somare,  on behalf of the Australian Government, deals with the land boundary of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and with the seabed boundary immediately south of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730502_reps_28_hor83/#subdebate-36-0)

* I said earlier that theloan will be the first raised by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> on international capital markets. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* But it is, as I inferred, not the first time that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has obtained overseas borrowings. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* In this case the loan will be to finance the public works and services of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* I have abstained from making remarks in this Parliament about the statements of the Minister for Civil Aviation  (Mr Charles Jones)  because I believed that it was only right that the matter be cooled and that a fresh and proper approach be taken to the national airline of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* But as this Bill is before the Parliament and as it refers to the opportunities for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to borrow overseas, it is related to the question of the development of an airline and the close association of Australia to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and it is necessary only a few days before the Minister's return to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to register a couple of points. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* [ reject the submission that has been made by the Minister for External Territories and  1  submit to you as persuasively as I can that the submission should be rejected for the following reasons: When we have a <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Loan Bill before us, it normally is for. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* In other words, it is a loan from international markets which will contribute to the budget of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* It is a very different loan Bill from the normal ones and I am entitled, I submit, under this particular Bill, to make reference to these matters which will come naturally, under the aegis of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> budget. * It refers to the financing of public works and services in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> which does not cover civil aviation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* The ruling given by the Chair - I reiterate it now - was that the Bill does not cover civil aviation in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* It is stressing the guarantee we are giving and providing <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> with the opportunity to go elsewhere. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* A contractual guarantee by the Australian Government for such a borrowing should ensure the success of this first issue and will materially assist <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in furthering Otis longer term objective. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* We trust that the negotiations on Friday will not broaden the difficulties of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in negotiating what is their own national airline. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730515_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-27-0)

* We very well know how important this period is for the foundation of Australia's future relationship with the independent nation of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will occupy a special position on Australia's network of relationships, but we do not seek an exclusive relationship with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> which will want to find her own place in the international community. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* As <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s foreign service develops and as her range of international interests grow, we shall be ready to help where we can and as we are asked. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will have the first call on our foreign aid program and we shall work closely with the central government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> through a specific and guaranteed economic program. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* We shall, however, place no inhibitions whatsoever on the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> &gt;n seeking aid or investment from any country she may choose to invite to take part in her development. * We are also anxious that outstanding questions relating to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s borders should be settled at an early date so that, when independence is attained, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s relations with her near neighbours will not be plagued by the kind of territorial disputes which in other parts of the world have done so much to hinder the development of fruitful and mutually beneficial relations between close neighbours. * We welcome the successful delineation of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> - Indonesia border. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* We attach considerable importance to the early negotiation of administrative arrangements between Australia - <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> on one hand and Indonesia on the other to avoid potential sources of friction on the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>-Indonesia border. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* I regret that despite my Government's best endeavours early progress towards agreement on the border between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> seems unlikely and final agreement may have to await <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* As well as the close personal, official and political links that have grown between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, there are several strong common interests which we share. * Similarly, in the other area of close interest to both of us, the South Pacific, we should, in the future, seek with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and our other friends in the Pacific to build on progress so far achieved in developing regional co-operation, friendship and partnership. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* The recent meeting of the Pacific Forum attended by both <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia was a useful step in this direction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* This year's overseas missions - to New Zealand, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Indonesia, the South Pacific Forum, Britain, the Vatican, Mauritius, India, Mexico, North America, Japan and China - are part of my responsibilities as Prime Minister, even more than as Foreign Minister. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730524_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-36-0)

* In the last year, there were some 25 assignments inside Australia and about 11 assignments outside Australia, in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Thailand, Cambodia, Malaysia or North Borneo. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730530_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-28-0)

* The  plannned  development  of  <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Forces would  be  seriously  set  back. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730530_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-33-0)

* National Service skills are important to this program, especially the 50 National Service teachers now preparing NCOs and  ORs  in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> for promotion. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730530_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-33-0)

* I realise why the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits scheme for the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Forces - that is another Bill that should have been introduced years ago; it is time it was introduced - is a funded scheme whereas the previous Government's scheme was non-funded. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730530_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-35-0)

* I believe that an agreement has been reached with the Chief Minister on this matter so that there will be no upset with its Public Service and police force when <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> finally gains its independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-39-1)

* No-one should underrate the continuing importance to Australia of a strong, friendly and united <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-39-1)

* Again, if <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> after independence became fragmented and if, for example, Bougainville separated and approaches to Bougainville were made by some great power for the concession of a naval base in return for aid, this again could have implications for Australia. * These were first, our own national security; secondly, a secure, united and friendly <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>; thirdly, achieve closer relations with our nearest and largest neighbour, Indonesia; fourthly, promote the peace and prosperity of our neighbourhood. * <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been alienated in the most arrogant fashion. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* Independence must be a matter for the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> or their representatives to decide. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* We are a colonial power only because we have an obligation to the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* It is not for us to say when <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be independent. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* We have a responsibility to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and we have an obligation on which we cannot and must not walk out. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* Under no circumstances and at no time now or in the future should we attempt to impose our will on the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> or their elected representatives. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* Again the Prime Minister has failed to assert control over his Ministers, one of whom arrogantly presumed to tell the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> how to run their airline system. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* As with all aid, this should be provided without strings and at the request of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government - not on a whim from Canberra. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* It was we who took the initiative in opposing our participation in the Vietnam conflict, in calling for more foreign aid, in proposing an end to racism in our international dealings, in co-operating with the movement of self government and independence for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and in opening up normal relations with China. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-53-0)

* Yes; so has the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730531_reps_28_hor84/#subdebate-60-8)

* He toured this country to the most remote places as he did <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730821_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-0-0)

* The Oppostion supports these amendments to the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act, which was originally introduced by the former Government to provide teachers for the Commonwealth schools in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, and also, we would hopefully believe, to provide security for Australian teachers in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> who might thereby be encouraged to stay in those Territories knowing that they would have security in being able to come back to the Commonwealth Teaching Service . * I was also pleased to see the reference in the second reading speech of the Minister for Education to the role that the Commonwealth Teaching Service may play in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the future. * That is an acknowledgement of the previous government's attitude towards support of the developing nation of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730821_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-115-0)

* I am one of those who believe that education in particular will offer a tremendous opportunity to the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to be able not only to develop their own culture but also to develop their own nation. * These concessions apply in respect of exploration and mining in Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730821_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-117-11)

* The process of localisation is proceeding effectively and at an increasing pace, although <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is likely to continue to require assistance from Australia for some time to come. * No threat of external military attack against <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is foreseen and we see no major risk to Australia's security arising there. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730822_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-54-0)

* Regarding internal security, honourable members will have noted the important statement on 20 August by the Minister for Defence and Foreign Relations in the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government,  Mr Kiki. * The Minister said that '<span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> was determined to look after its own security problems in the future' and: [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730822_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-54-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730822_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-54-0)

* I would like to know whether the flow of teachers is to come from the Territory of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> into the north of Australia or vice versa. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730822_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-61-0)

* If we can assist not only <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> but also other places then we will be doing a service to humanity and particularly to those people in areas in which Australia should be playing a part. * Its purpose is to bring about formal self-government in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> by amending the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Act and by providing the means by which other Australian legislation may be discontinued in its application to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. * This legislation marks a significant step towards nationhood for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730823_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-46-0)

* In addition there are 2 Bills which amend specific Australian Acts in their application to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730823_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-46-0)

* These amendments result from agreements reached between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> for the transfer of the function of the Bureau of Meteorology to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and the exclusion of that country from the operation of the Wireless Telegraphy Act. * In practice <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is virtually self-governing now. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730823_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-46-0)

* The previous Australian Government accepted the wishes of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> that the date for self-government be 1 December 1973 or as soon as possible thereafter. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730823_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-46-0)
