* As we have promised to keep our remarks short, I will merely congratulate the Minister for External Territories again upon the decision to have a parliamentary delegation visit <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I hope that it will not be the last parliamentary delegation to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* in reply - I believe that it has been encouraging for all of us to see the sense of responsibility with which this House has approached what is in fact an historic act in providing for the self-government and eventual independence of the Australian colony of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We members of the Australian Labor Party, mindful of this experience, decided not this year but several years ago that our policy would be to bring <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to self-government and independence not through conflict but by the colonial power saying: 'We believe that you have a right to make your decisions in your own way. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In 1970 the present Prime Minister  (Mr Whitlam),  as Leader of the Opposition, went to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We said then that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> was ready for self-government and that independence was not that far off. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* At the same time there was a change of government in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and  Mr Michael  Somare became the Chief Minister in a national coalition government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We had met  Mr Michael  Somare when he was in Opposition in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and we were in Opposition in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* What happened in 1972 was that the then Government had the presence of mind to accept the inevitability of that which we as the Labor Party in Opposition had put forward and that which the new Chief Minister of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> had put forward. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I think that as Australians we can all be proud that we are bringing <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to independence not through conflict or violence but through constitutional procedures in this House and in the House of Assembly of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* There was, I suppose, an element of shadow-sparring on the part of the Opposition, for example, concerning the extent to which we should consult with, take notice of and act in conjunction with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I reiterate that all steps taken to date and all steps planned for the future have been agreed between the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and the Australian Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In the period that I have been Minister for External Territories there have been 4 substantial changes in the approved arrangements under sections 24 and 25 of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Act. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Each of these changes has been at the request of and in consultation with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I have made frequent visits to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Discussions have been held not only with Government leaders and leaders of the coalition, party, but also with members of the Opposition, members of the Constitutional Planning Committee and town councillors throughout the length and breadth of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have agreed in consultation with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> that there will be a 2 stage development in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in which the opportunity would be given to the Constitutional Planning Committee and, through it, the House of Assembly for a home grown constitution. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Our policy is that the date for independence will be achieved in the closest consultation with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* It will be subject to the endorsement of the House of Assembly /as representing the view of the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Special Committee notes with satisfaction that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is making steady progress towards the achievement of the goals proclaimed in resolution 1514 (XV) and that progressive steps to this end are being taken by the administering Power. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Special Committee endorses the view that the House of Assembly, as the duly elected representatives of the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, in consultation with the administering Power, should decide the date for the attainment of independence of the Territory in the light of General Assembly resolution 2977 (XXVII) of 14 December 1972. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Pursuant to that resolution, the Special Committee calls upon the administering Power, in consultation with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, to prepare a timetable for independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I speak of  Sir Robert  Menzies who, back in I960, I think, made the observation that if there is to be independence for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> it is better sooner rather than later. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The accusation has been made, somewhat lightly, I suppose, as there was not a great deal of sincerity in the viewpoint put by various speakers, that we are rushing into independence and that we are not providing sufficient opportunities and facilities for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to play its part. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* It has been our policy, it is our policy and it will continue to be our policy to give <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> an international identity not only before independence but also before self government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We as a Government have sponsored membership by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> of such international organisations as the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, the Asian Development Bank, the World Health Organisation, the South Pacific Commission and the International Labour Organisation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have sought to encourage other countries to take an interest in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Other countries such as New Zealand, Germany and Japan are discussing with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> the establishment of representation in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> ahead of independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have accepted the most urgent need for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to enter nationhood in a harmonious relationship with its neighbour, Indonesia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I might recall that a Committee of this House in the previous Parliament - the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs through its Sub-Committee on Australia's Relations with Indonesia - recorded in its report the importance of this close relationship being developed between Australia, Indonesia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In the determination of the boundary between West Irian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and in the negotiations on a border regime, the Committee recognises the importance of the active participation of the representatives of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Australia's role in resolving these two matters is to ensure that relations between Indonesia and the new state of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> are established on a firm and harmonious basis and that Australia in discharging its responsibilities maintains the respect of and cordial relations with both countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* But, on assuming responsibility for this portfolio, I immediately put arrangements in hand and the border between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Indonesia has now been delineated. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Discussions are taking place this very day in Djakarta on the border arrangements between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and West Irian. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* One of the primary responsibilities and tasks of this aid agency will be continuing assistance to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have accepted the special relationship between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* By this commitment to a timetable for assistance, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be in a better position to plan its own development. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have stated also that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will have first call on Australia's foreign aid. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We accept the responsibility to ensure that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is in a position to develop for the good of its own people in the way that the elected representatives of the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and not of Australia, should so decide. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have made it very clear that, in this period, we will operate in the closest consultation with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I might point out to honourable gentlemen opposite that it was because of their complete neglect and their complete incompetence that the Minister for Defence  (Mr Barnard)  and I have had to put a great deal of effort into ensuring a sensible program in the defence relationships between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the future. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Australia has been gravely at fault in delaying so long a separation of the armed forces in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> from those of Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We called it the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Defence Force. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* This re-designation parade is an important and historic occasion in the development of the armed forces of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and of the identification of the forces within the country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have had these discussions with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> through the Minister for Defence as a result of his visit there within the first month - in January - of assuming office. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In these discussions with the Chief Minister of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> it was agreed that consultations on defence matters would commence in March between officials of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and the Australian Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* We have made it our firm view - our firm conviction: - that the ultimate decision concerning <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s defence capability, its structure and role will rest with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Our role in these consultations has been to advise and to assist in the decision making processes and to bring to the attention of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> authorities all factors relevant to the formulation of a suitable defence policy for an .independent <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* So all the questions of organisation, role, size, localisation and training of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Defence Force is now a matter for close and continuing consultation with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In fact in May 1973 the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government issued policy guidelines in proceeding with the defence arrangements after the achievment of independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Minister for Defence has been in close consultation with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and we are convinced that this is the right way to proceed because the nature of the Defence Force for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is primarily a matter for the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government itself to decide. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* I believe these ministerial arrangements are a measure of the degree of forward planning for which this Government has been responsible in the approach to this very important matter of the independence of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* In this period between selfgovernment and independence there will be a Minister Assisting the Minister for Foreign Affairs in regard to matters affecting <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Department and the Minister for Foreign Affairs will assume the responsibility for Australia's relations with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Because of the importance that we attach to the smooth transfer, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Foreign Affairs in regard to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> matters will be given the responsibility for coordinating all the matters relating to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* Other Ministers who have statutory responsibility in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, such as the Minister for Defence, have been asked by the Prime Minister to consult with the Minister Assisting in discharging their own responsibilities so as to ensure adequate coordination. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Minister Assisting, in consultation with other Ministers who have a responsibility for particular subjects involved, will co-ordinate the negotiation of such agreements between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> as may be needed between now and independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The Minister Assisting will also coordinate the activities of the relevant Australian departments in regard to the final stages of the handing over of powers to the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and the final steps to independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* This will be known as the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Office. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* It will be staffed by officers with experience in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> affairs now serving with the Department of External Territories. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The head of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Office, who will serve the Minister Assisting, will chair the standing interdepartmental committee on <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* The High Commissioner in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be appointed as at 1 December 1973 to take the place of the office of the present Administrator and during the self-government period he will be responsible to the Minister Assisting for all the matters undertaken by the Minister. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* As I pointed out in my second reading speech, these are historic Bills but I believe that with the co-operation of all groups within Australia, with the continuing cooperation of the Government, the House of Assembly and the people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> we can bring about an orderly transfer of authority from a colonial power to its former colony. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730925_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-25-0)

* One needs only to compare the actions of this Government in relation to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> with the paternalistic attitude that is now shown by the Minister towards these 2 areas to justify what I am saying. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730927_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-45-0)

* This Government forced <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> along the road to self-government and independence at a speed at which the people of that country did not want to travel. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730927_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-45-0)

* Using a word that the Minister used so freely in his speech, I refer to the hypocrisy of the attitude of this Government when one sees what it is doing in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> by speeding it to selfgovernment and independence and compare that with the callous attitude of the Minister towards the people of these 2 Territories. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19730927_reps_28_hor85/#subdebate-45-0)

* This Banking Bill is one of 4 Australian Bills required to transfer the responsibility for the control and supervision of banking in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and its authorities and to pave the way for the establishment of a separate <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> banking system and central bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* At present the Australian Government's legislation, namely the Reserve Bank Act, the Banking Act and the Commonwealth Banks Act, extends to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and, accordingly, the responsibility for control and supervision of banking in that country rests with the Australian Government and, in particular, with the Reserve Bank of Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The effect of these Bills will be to withdraw the application of this Australian legislation to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> at a date to be agreed with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and to facilitate the transfer of responsibilities. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* It will also open the way for the development of a banking and financial system appropriate to the particular needs and circumstances of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and will ensure control by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the planning of future developments in these areas. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The development of a separate banking system for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> was the subject of a detailed examination by a committee of Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government officials established by the previous Australian Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The report of that committee, which was tabled in the Australian Parliament on 29 August 1973, was accepted in principle by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government as a suitable basis for action to establish a separate banking system in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The principles on which the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> banking system is to be established were set out in a joint Press statement which was issued by the Minister for External Territories  (Mr Morrison),  the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Minister for Finance and myself in April 1973. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* Those principles include: That responsibility for control of banks and financial institutions operating in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> be vested in the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> authorities as soon as practicable; that a central bank be established in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> on the basis of the Port Moresby office of the Reserve Bank of Australia and be endowed with a full range of powers to act as a central monetary authority for a separate banking system, even though some of these powers could not be usedin the immediate future; that a national banking institution be established in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> through the setting up of a new <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government commercial bank; and that except where certain accounts give rise to special contractual or financial problems the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> business of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation be transferred to the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government Commercial Bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* These principles are embodied in 2 ordinances relating to banking which have recently been passed by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> House of Assembly. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The first of these ordinances is the Central Banking Ordinance which authorises the establishment of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s own central bank to be called the Bank of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The Australian Government included in its grant to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> this financial year financial assistance to help in the establishment of this new central bank. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* The <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government has indicated its intention, if possible, to bring these 2 ordinances into force on 1 November 1973. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* Since the Australian banking legislation extends at present to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government can bring these ordinances into operation only when the application of the Australian banking legislation to that country is withdrawn. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* I commend to the House this Banking Bill, designed to allow the withdrawal of the application of the Australian Banking Act to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and the other associated Bills which I am introducing concurrently to facilitate the establishment of a separate banking system in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731010_reps_28_hor86/#subdebate-26-0)

* I believe that their contribution to the self-government and to the status of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> must be a great tribute to their own personal efforts. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731129_reps_28_hor87/#subdebate-27-0)

* To Michael Somare, the Chief Minister of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and to his parliamentarians the responsibility for the future is now passed. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731129_reps_28_hor87/#subdebate-27-0)

* I believe that in Michael Somare and his Ministry there is the capacity for the guidance of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the future in a sound and constructive way. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1973/19731129_reps_28_hor87/#subdebate-27-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> boats have been fishing in the area for many years; we have never restricted them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

*  The Opposition supports this Bill, but it is concerned that in a discussion about fishing there should be a recognition of the implications of the transfer of powers, which the Fisheries (<span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Boats) Bill is all about. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* It is intended to make sure that the foreign boat category includes boats of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the same way as Australian legislation now excludes all other boats. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* That is that the Bill is part of the transfer of powers to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> towards its exercising of the complete functions of a self governing independent country as from 1 December 1974. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* In passing the powers from the Australian Parliament to that of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> the legislation does not canvass the implications of fishing and the intertwining of fishing rights in areas that are adjacent to both countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Indeed, the necessity for the legislation to recognise licences granted under Australian legislation for boats registered in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> comes out of the specific exclusion that is within clause 4 of the Bill. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The agreement arrived at in initial discussions that took place between Chief Minister Michael Somare, my friend the honourable member for Kooyong  (Mr Peacock),  who spoke a few moments ago, and I for the purpose of trying to establish a basis by which <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> boats could operate in Australian proclaimed waters has largely been adopted in subsequent discussions between the present Prime Minister  (Mr Whitlam)  and Chief Minister Somare. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* It is a difficult area because the boats that are operating from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> waters fall into the 2 classes to which I have referred. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* There is no dispute about the rights of the indigenous Papuan New Guinea fishermen operating in waters in the Torres Strait and elsewhere where the 2 countries traditionally or Papua New Guineans in particular and people from the Torres Strait Islands have exercised their fishing interests. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The difficulties that have emerged have come out of the very natural desire that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has had to see its fishing responsibilities extended into a viable commercial arena. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Some Middle East capital has been invested in fishing operations in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* We were conscious in the discussions with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> that it was necessary that we try to meet the twin objectives of encouraging <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s commercial development of a fishing industry on a larger scale, but equally of not prejudicing the operation of Australian fishing boats. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* A reasonable compromise has been reached and I hope that in the operation of future agreements that will be necessary for fishing in Australian proclaimed waters it will continue to be possible for a reconciliation of the difficulties that we see in meeting these twin objectives, namely, that of encouraging <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s commercial development and a commercial fishing industry without prejudicing the operation of Australian fishing boats, particularly in the Gulf of Carpenteria. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* But I did want to advert to fishing in this area because I believe that we have an interest in Australia in helping <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> towards the establishment of a commercial industry. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* It is a particular problem because of the dispute which still exists between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia over the future territorial boundaries between the 2 countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I think it is important that we recognise that a great deal needs to be done for a country like <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, as for Australia, to ensure that there is adequate knowledge of what the fish, sea and ocean resources might be before the full advantages of this other form of natural resource can be exploited. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I hope that in the transfer of power there will continue to be co-operation in the field of developing an understanding of what ocean resources exist, to what extent they might be available for exploitation and how they can be best turned to the commercial advantage of both <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I think that apart from the general aid that we provide for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, meaningful financial assistance can be provided specifically in this field, in order to ensure that both countries understand their ocean resources and that both countries can utilise them in terms of the exercise of their own sovereign responsibilities - that which is about to be exercised as a result of the passage of this Bill and that which is still exercised and will continue to be exercised by Australian governments in the exercise of their residual fishing responsibility within our own constitutional responsibility and within our own territorial waters and proclaimed waters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I believe that Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> would have a common interest in ensuring the maximum possible jurisdiction over fishing within this legislation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Whatever the resolution of the extent of territorial waters, I believe that it is important for countries like <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia not only to gain the maximum jurisdiction over these waters but also to ensure that they take advantage of the fishing rights within those waters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* As I have said, it is also important that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia maintain a research program and a co-operative effort. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I believe that we have to be very conscious of the effect that any licenses which are granted for the commercial exploitation of fishing waters, particularly those Australian proclaimed waters to the north in which a commercial industry operating in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> might wish to fish, might have on the interests of indigenous Australian fishermen. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The Bill simply transfers to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> a responsibility which in the past we have exercised. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* But in the exercise of the responsibility which henceforth will be that of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> there is I think a necessity for both of our countries to maintain the closest possible liaison to ensure that the fishing and ocean resources can be exploited to the mutual advantage of both of our countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The honourable member stated that the Government had done nothing since coming to office to resolve the border dispute between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* On IS December 1972 when I was half the Government I wrote to the Premier of Queensland suggesting that officials of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Queensland and the Australian Government hold discussions on this issue. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Since then ministerial and official discussions have been held between the Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Governments. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* There have been consultations with the Torres Strait Islanders, and discussions have been arranged between the Torres Strait Islanders and the coastal people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The issues have not yet been discussed between the Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> governments. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* When this week the Premier of Queensland proposed to telephone the Chief Minister of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> about the matter, the Chief Minister got in touch with me and I encouraged a discussion between him and the Premier. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* He realises that it is not possible for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to reach a separate agreement with Queensland. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* When <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> becomes independent, presumably before the end of this year, negotiations will take place - as international law negotiations can only take place - between the Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> governments only. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* However, in view of the Premier's changed attitude about discussions with the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government, I have again invited him to take part in official discussions with the Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> governments with a view to reaching an agreed settlement. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

*  This Bill transferring jurisdiction for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> fishing boats is relatively short but its implications are considerable. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Like Australia, <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is an island, and many of the comments which apply to Australia apply also to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Just as in this country the fishing industry is one of the most rapidly developing primary industries, so I am sure the development and exploitation of the fisheries resources will be important to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Historically the industry in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been a fairly simple one - simple in the sense of the equipment which has been used until now. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* As in Australia there is a growing emphasis on larger vessels and more sophisticated equipment, this change in emphasis will apply to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, although perhaps not to quite the same degree. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Of course historically these resources have been a considerable source of protein in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and that will continue. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* But if experience along the northern Australian coast is any guide - I am sure that it is - there must be considerable opportunities for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to develop and expand an export industry in fisheries products. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* As I was saying, there will be every opportunity for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> through development of its fisheries resources not only to make a valuable contribution to its own food supplies but also, if experience in northern Australian waters is a guide - I said I thought it would be a guide - to develop export possibilities for the fishing industry. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Certainly in the earlier days of independence <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will have difficulty finding the research funds which will be necessary to determine all that needs to be known about its fishing grounds, the types of fish available, their habits and so on. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* It is also true that a great deal of the research in Australian fishery resources is being carried out in waters adjacent to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> "waters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* With all that research going on up there, basically for our own purposes, I hope that as results that could be valuable to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> become available the Austraiian Government will see to it that that country is kept informed of the latest results of our research in those waters so that in turn <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> can benefit from it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* No doubt eventually <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will initiate projects of its own, but in the early days I believe that Australia can make a valuable contribution without any additional expenditure of money - merely by seeing that what benefits we have gained from our research are, if applicable, communicated to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* One of the problems that I imagine <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will face is that of meeting the export standards of many countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Here again I imagine that our own Department of Primary Industry and perhaps the Department of Health could be of considerable assistance in advising <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> on standards required in processing plants and the testing of samples to make sure that they comply with international world health standards. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Inevitably that will be an area of difficulty for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in its early years of self government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The Bill before the House is of very great significance because it facilitates the full administrative arrangements necessary in the self-government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in respect of the fishing industry. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I am sure that this House would want to assist the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to the greatest possible extent in the smoothest possible transference of powers of this kind. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The fishing industry has particular significance to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Firstly, there is the circumstance that fishing is really part and parcel of the sustenance of very many people around the coastline of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, and in particular it is of great importance to their welfare and their future stability in terms not only of sustenance but also of the gradual development of commercial fishing. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* In that area lying between the territory of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia there has been a degree of concern as to the future of the actual line of demarcation; in other words, the border between the 2 territories. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I believe it is a matter of extreme importance from the point of view of our relationships with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to co-operate in every way to ensure that the administration of the fishing industry avoids any of the sensitive areas of administration which so often cause friction between countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* We must take another aspect into consideration, namely, the carry through of what I was saying about the importance of fishing to the individual Papua New Guineans along the coastline. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* With the advent of scientific techniques in fishing around the world and with the gradual development of standards in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, undoubtedly a situation will arise in which more sophisticated equipment will be used than hitherto has been the case. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I refer to the legislation which has been enacted in the Parliament of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I presume too that we have assisted to make possible the best law for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and in so doing have ensured that the interpretation of that law will apply in the interests of both countries, because it would be folly indeed for us to have a situation in which there was any variation in interpretation of the fishing laws of Australia and the fishing laws of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* One can well imagine similar situations arising in the waters of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, bearing in mind that undoubtedly commercial fishing ventures will be developed in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> waters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* These commercial ventures could be undertaken for the very good reason that the fishing grounds of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> have already been assessed and shown to have good resources in the various categories of fish. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Commercial enterprises, undoubtedly, will become a factor in the growing economy of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Certainly, I would assume that Australia, as the country that has the greatest responsibility to assist <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, would want to help with the development of an effective viable commercial fishing industry in that country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I believe that there can be an effective relationship between our 2 countries provided that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> does not grant rights that are too easily won, or should I say that do not involve reasonable conditions and restraints on those who might want to go into ventures that the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> may propose or that others may propose to it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* We do not want to see undue intrusion into those waters by interests based on <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I trust that the Government has considered this aspect carefully in the drafting of this legislation and in its negotiations with the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I hope that we will be co-operating closely with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to ensure that it too observes this most necessary precaution - a precaution that could well mean that in the long term we preserve an effective supply of fish, fish oil and other fish products to sustain the protein requirements of big consumers of fish and at the same time to participate in the world market for the supply of fish from the seas. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Firstly, we must ensure that the best scientific advice is followed and, secondly, that we co-operate with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in the construction and the standards for construction of boats. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The scope of ship building in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is limited. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I can recall seeing a small slipway at Madang where efforts were being made to construct fishing boats of the kind that could be operated in the waters of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* I do not know what has happened to that venture over the last couple of years but it is the kind of venture that we should do all we can to support and encourage, not in terms of creating competition for our own fishermen but in terms of creating a capacity in fishing that will ensure that the waters of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> are not unduly exploited but that an effective approach, to the care of fishing grounds is considered. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Finally Australia, of course, is assisting <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> financially to a very great extent. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* In the long run this will produce for the area north of Australia and the regions around <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, which are important to Australia, a fishing industry in the best interests of both countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Various points of view were put forward regarding some vital issues in relation to future determinations about territorial boundaries and fishing in so-called international waters lying between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The honourable member for Cowper  (Mr Ian Robinson)  also sounded a note of caution with respect to not only Papua New Guinean boats but boats from other countries coming into the grey areas of Australian proclaimed waters such as those off the coast of New South Wales, Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Gulf of Carpentaria. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* If the Bill is passed it will of course give <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> complete control of the administration of its own fishing laws. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Under the present laws any boats from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in Australian proclaimed waters come under the jurisdiction of the Australian Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* This amendment to the Fisheries Act will alter that and will mean that boats from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be treated in exactly the same way as all other foreign boats coming into Australian waters, fishing zones, territorial sea waters or whatever it might be, keeping in mind of course any bilateral agreements which might exist between the 2 countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* The honourable member for Cowper raised a point regarding the type of legislation that was passed by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> House of Assembly. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* This hope was that it would allow for co-operation between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> or, for that matter, any other country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* That certainly can be achieved and will be achieved by the Act that has been passed by the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government in relation to the Australian laws. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19740404_reps_28_hor88/#subdebate-21-0)

* Briefly, this legislation provides for increased tax liabilities for the mining industry, the imposition of taxation on certain forms of fringe benefits, the specific allowance of deductions for depreciation on child care facilities, a reduction of the limit on deductions for educational expenses, the deductibility of mortgage interest payments, a reduced level of the special deduction allowable to life assurance companies, a rebate of dependants' allowances for low income families; and technical amendments fo the principal Act with respect to dividends payable from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, the relief of taxpayers in cases of hardship and provisional tax for 1974-75. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741126_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-15-0)

* The Opposition Parties support the proposals in respect of the hardship of taxpayers and dividends from <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741126_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-15-0)

* With legislation for certain borrowings from the United States Export-Import Bank and with guarantees to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development for borrowings by <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, it has been possible to schedule to the legislation the agreements for the loans. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741128_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-36-0)

* The Bill provides for Australia to accede to the Convention with a declaration that it is to extend to all our external territories except <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741202_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-35-0)

* Naturally the Agency is deeply concerned with Australia's assistance to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741202_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-38-0)

* In addition it is worth pointing out that there is a separate <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> office attached to the Department of Foreign Affairs with its own economic branch and in the Department of Foreign Affairs there is also a <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> section which is supposed to examine Australia's political associations with that country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741202_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-38-0)

* By the end of the current financial year, based on the estimates provided in the 1974-75 Budget, Australia will have made available a total of $2,650m to developing countries, more than half of which has been provided to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741202_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-38-0)

* If the Government's recent undertaking to the World Food Conference is taken into account, our development assistance for the current financial year will amount to more than $350m with a further $ 1 87m going to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741202_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-38-0)

* It was introduced into <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> by those who sit opposite. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-12-0)

* -These Bills are far more important than either the Minister for Foreign Affairs in Matters Relating to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>  (Mr Morrison)  or the Government has divulged. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* This is in keeping with the manner in which some aspects of the administration of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> have been carried out during this Government's period of office. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* With the utmost respect to the judges of the Supreme Court of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, it seems to me that it is most necessary to give them the security provided by this legislation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* The transfer of the functions of the Supreme Court to the control of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is a most important matter from the domestic point of view, and the Opposition supports it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* We commend the provisions dealing with the lower courts, the House of Assembly, electoral matters and trie repeal of appeals to the High Court of Australia, just as we commend the smooth and early transition of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> to independence. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* This means that we are transferring two most important reserve powers to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, namely, the power over defence matters and the power over foreign affairs. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* If that is the case, I should have thought that, if not the Minister for Science, at least the man who ran away from the responsibility of answering for both the administration of defence services in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and more importantly the arrangements between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in a postindependence scene ought to have been prepared to tell us in this Parliament what the arrangements will be either after this Bill is passed and in due course is proclaimed or after independence what the relations between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will be in the defence sphere. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* We are now moving towards the most important stage in the history of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* At independence Australia's United Nations obligations will be discharged and a new set of relations between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will need to be developed. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* But where is the information regarding this new set of relations that is to exist between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* I know that in relation to fisheries and other fields statements have been issued by respective Ministers indicating what the relationship of administrative and legal functions will be under either joint or several arrangements between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and ourselves. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Whilst I was the Minister for External Territories the Government of which I was a member agreed that we would discuss well before independence what the relations after independence would be, on the very axiomatic point that this takes some time to develop, that it would not be in Australia's national interest or indeed in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s interest to wait until the date is reached and then look at one another, as it were, and determine how we are going to go about things. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* As I say, we wanted this not only in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>'s interest, but also in Australia's interest. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* But what study of Australia's national interests in relation to our arrangements with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been done? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* I trust that the Minister when he comes round to replying in this debate will inject some certainty for those who are concerned about post-independence relations between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and will advise us. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* It is important because after this piece of legislation apart from, as I understand it, certain Australian defence legislation that applies equally to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and will have to be eradicated so that it applies only to Australia, there will be an independence Bill and the final obliteration of the remnants of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Act which is being amended by this Bill, and little else. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* We know its reluctance generally but why the reluctance in regard to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, that country which has a special relationship with us over and above any other relationship that we have had with any other country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* I would say that if we examine the relationship between metropolitan powers and administered entities- whether it be with African countries, whether it be Fiji and the United Kingdom or what other entity one chooses- we would see that there has probably not been an administered area which was as close to the metropolitan power, not geographically but in the way it moved towards its independence- as <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> used to be to us. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* The Constitutional Planning Committee in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> last year said that. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* And, of course, the words of the Minister a couple of weeks ago in a statement in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> conflicted with a statement he made in this House, or appeared to do so by Press reports. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* This unique situation which is unsatisfactory both to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia will not and cannot continue any longer. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* It is a period in which we have desisted from making any statement that could seem to be, or could be seen to be, an interference in the affairs of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* I think that the honourable member with his keen awareness of the developments in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> would recognise that in fact, in reality, there was no distinction between what he said and what he was reported to have said but a very real distinction between either one of the variants that have been put to us and what was said here. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* He has been a good Minister in regard to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and I do not want to spend time denigrating the efforts he has made in developing a close relationship with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* It ought to be pointed out for the record on this important occasion on which almost the penultimate Bill on <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been brought into this Parliament. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* If <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is to become independent in a matter of months, surely its territorial jurisdiction ought to be certain. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* As I say, it may only be a matter of months, less than 12 months, until <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> becomes independent. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* The second and most important aspect is that on which I touched earlier concerning the question of our defence forces and the relationship between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* In clause 3 of this Bill Australia proposes to transfer the power over foreign relations and defence to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* These powers will cease to be reserve powers to Australia- reserve in the sense that when <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> achieved self government on 1 December 1973 certain powers remained with the metropolitan powerAustralia namely, defence, foreign affairs, the supreme court and certain other stated matters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* I put it to the House that other than the 5 pages of the statement made by the Minister for Defence  (Mr Barnard)  on 24 October, we have heard virtually nothing from this Government in regard to defence arrangements between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Frankly, as I read them, these 5 pages of that statement seem to me to be a rhetorical embellishment of what we knew, that is that Australia has been abdicating its duties and its responsibilities in determining a proper and cohesive arrangement between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Of course one would get that from the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* It tells us that the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> defence force will have a strength of 3,500 uniformed servicemen, with 2 infantry battalions, an engineers company, a patrol boat squadron and a landing craft squadron. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* There can be no question that ultimate responsibility Tor the defence of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will lie with Australia until the trusteeship agreement is terminated. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* that on the date on which <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> shall become independent the Trusteeship Agreement for the Territory of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> approved by the United Nations General Assembly on 13 December 1946 shall cease to be in force; [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* requests the administering power to notify the Secretary-General of the date on which <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will accede to independence and on which the Trusteeship Agreement shall cease to be in force. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* The object of it clearly is that this, the 29th session of the United Nations General Assembly, meeting now, must do this because <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> may be independent before the 30th session of the General Assembly commences. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Why not tell us that what the Government is in fact doing is providing for an arrangement whereby when <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> becomes independent all the Australian Government will have to do is write a letter to the SecretaryGeneral of the United Nations telling the United Nations this and Australia's answerability to that forum is finished and completed? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* ultimate responsibility for the defence of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> will lie with Australia until the Trusteeship Agreement is terminated. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* But there will be no forum in which to question it or to probe or to analyse what is transpiring unless there is such a holocaust in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> that the relevant body of the United Nations is called together specifically to discuss that holocaust. * What are the arrangements between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia therefore? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* But how many of these men will be integrated within the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> defence force? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* How many will be under the direct control and order of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> defence force itself? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* The remaining 423 persons will be playing a role along the guidelines produced by the Minister for Defence in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>,  Mr Albert  Maori Kiki, if there is any need to bring out the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> defence force in support of the police- in other words, in support of the civil power or to put down any form of uprising. * I do not suggest that to inject a pessimistic note into the future of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* But the Minister for Defence in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>- as the honourable member for Boothby reminds me by saying that it is a possibility- has put down guidelines as to the circumstances in which servicemen could be used. * To what extent will <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> be meeting some of the bill? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Will <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> be able to carry that expenditure into the turn of the century? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* As far as aid is concerned, we will treat <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> in a special relationship, as I term it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* So many times I have said that <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> is deserving of additional aid over and above the aid other recipient countries obtain from Australia because <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has been so closely associated with us at law, geographically and within the ambit of the trusteeship agreement. * Hopefully it does not apply, though, in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* So I have no objection to the transfer of control over the Supreme Court and local courts and over the provisions in the Judges' Pensions Bill which provides pensions for Australians who were appointed prior to 1 December 1973 to serve on the Supreme Court of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. * The Opposition has not sought to make political capital out of the Government's administration of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* You have produced too much pace and pressure on the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* They do not wish to disclose just what they are up to in relation to the use of Australian servicemen in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* This is the third occasion on which I have had the privilege or otherwise of following the honourable gentleman in debates relating to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)

* Australia owe a debt of gratitude to the honourable gentleman for the contribution which he has made in regard to the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Bill (No. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1974/19741203_reps_29_hor92/#subdebate-22-0)
