* These men represent all parts of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and are likely to be its leaders for many years to come. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751001_reps_29_hor96/#subdebate-47-1)

* The Public Service continues to grow and this Will be a problem for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751001_reps_29_hor96/#subdebate-47-1)

* The traditional sense of kinship obligation will make this a distinct probability in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751001_reps_29_hor96/#subdebate-47-1)

* I emphasise that it was our contribution, from Australian taxpayers' money, that bought for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> a fair equity in the copper mines. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-22-0)

* He also knows the keen interest that the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> has shown in what it deems to be a fair and reasonable return from taxation of the profits. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-22-0)

* The honourable member would know that the sense of balance the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government has is the same as any reputable country would have. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-22-0)

* The honourable member knows the difficulties of Kennacott in perhaps abandoning some of its explorations in <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-22-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-32-0)

* by leave- On 7 October the Premier of Queensland, in a statement to the Queensland Parliament, accused the Australian Government of double-dealing and blackmail over the question of the border between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* They affect the long-term relationships between Australia and the newly-independent nation of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* The issue of the border between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia is not one which was created by or is peculiar to the policies of this [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* The need for an agreed definition of that boundary was an inevitable consequence of the policy of independence for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* Whatever the views of the Australian Government about the rights or wrongs of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> claim for an adjustment to the border, that Government- whatever its political complexion- would have been faced on the one hand by a clear demand for adjustment by the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and on the other by the unwillingness of the Queensland Government to accept any change. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* The Australian Government, therefore, from the outset, made clear its position that the location of the border should be determined by negotiation between the Australian and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> governments, with the Australian Government accepting the responsibility to take account of the constitutional and other interests of the Government of the State of Queensland and particularly to protect the interests of Torres Strait Islanders. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* Accordingly, within a fortnight of our coming into office, I wrote to the Premier suggesting discussions between officials of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Queensland and Australian governments to help resolve these matters. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* In discussions in January 1973 with  Mr Somare,  then Chief Minister of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, I expressed quite clearly the Government's desire to resolve this issue in friendly negotiation and indicated that the Government would be most reluctant to accept a settlement of the issue which was unacceptable to Torres Strait Islanders. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* It was evident at this time that complex negotiations between the Australian Government and the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> would be necessary to resolve these issues and that the Australian Government would need, in parallel with these, to be carrying on discussions with the Torres Strait Islanders and with the Government of Queensland. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* It seemed to me important, in preparing for these negotiations, that I should take action to ensure that the interests and views of Torres Strait Islanders were at all times taken into account in discussions within the Australian Government Administration leading up to negotiations with <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> or to discussions with the Queensland Government. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-33-0)

* The consultations on Yam Island and at Daru were discussions between the Islanders and the coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* Furthermore the Department of Foreign Affairs has taken action to acquaint officials of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> with the views expressed in it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* During the morning of Saturday, 20 September, time was taken out from the normal agenda of the conference to enable  Dr Coombs  to outline to the chairmen the content of  Sir Maori  Kiki 's letter of 8 September, to draw attention to the issues which had emerged in discussions with Queensland and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and to draw the Islanders' attention to the need to consider them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* They stated, however, that, if a border through the protected zone was necessary to prevent a serious dispute and possible ill-will between the Governments and people of Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, they would be prepared to consider accepting it, providing their essential interests were protected. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* The Conference of Torres Strait Islands Chairmen decided that while they wished to remain free to consider the future of the border between Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and their attitude towards it, the following statement could for the present be used by the Australian Government in its discussions as a guide to Torres Strait Islanders' attitude to the questions involved. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* The Islanders believe that the present discussions between the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Australian, and Queensland Governments about the border between <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and Australia are based on a misunderstanding of the traditional relationship between Torres Strait Islanders and coastal residents of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Mainland. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* If some change in the border is necessary, the Islanders see no reason why it should run through the proposed protected zone which they believe could be maintained as a region within which Islanders and the coastal peoples of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> bordering on the Straits could live harmoniously as they have in past ages. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* They believe that the Governments of Australia and <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> could work out a form of joint control which would be adequate in a zone where the protection of the environment and the embargo on mining and oil drilling would make many of the issues requiring the exercise of sovereignty unlikely or less difficult. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> Government and people and the Governments and people of Queensland and Australia, the Islanders would be prepared to consider accepting such a border providing the following conditions are met. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* The Governments of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, Australia and Queensland to agree to the establishment of an environmentally protected zone or marine park controlled so as to ensure the preservation of the total environment of the Torres Strait- the Islands, reefs and cays, the sea and seabed, and the air above it including the natural wild life and marine creatures as the basis for the traditional way of life of the Islanders and the coastal people of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> bordering on the Straits. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* This protected zone to extend from the coast of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> bordering on Straits to include all areas of the Straits used by the Islanders including Bramble Cay, the Barrier Reef, Deliverance Island and Turn Cay. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* That all new commercial ventures in this zone be subject to control to ensure that they will not damage the environment, that they are substantially owned and controlled by local residents and that the consent of the Representatives of the Islanders and the residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> bordering on Torres Strait has been given to their establishment. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* The Islanders and coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> bordering on the Torres Strait to be effectively represented on any body appointed to administer the Protected Zone (or Marine Park) or to advise Governments in relation to it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* That there be complete embargo on new mining and oil drilling or exploration for ten ( 10) years; the embargo to be continued thereafter unless agreed by the three Governments after the views of the Representatives of the Islanders and coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> have been taken into account. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* Royalties to be paid to Trustees appointed by the local community most affected and by the Representatives of Torres Strait Islanders and coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and to be used for the benefit of these people. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* If any Treaty or Agreement relating to this matter is to be terminated other by agreement or by one party, the Governments agree to confer with the Representatives of the Islanders and of coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> and if agreement cannot be reached about arrangements to follow those provided for in the Treaty or Agreement the question to be referred to the International Court or to some other Arbitrator acceptable to the Representatives of the Islanders and coastal residents of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

* -by leave-With a degree of false modesty I put forward the proposition that despite the visits that Australian politicians have made to <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>, no one in this Parliament has discussed either at such length or so frequently as I have the question of the Queensland-<span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span> border with members of the Government of <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>. * I also submit that no one has raised in this Parliament since the Australian Labor Party was elected to Government the question of the <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>-Queensland border as frequently as I have. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1975/19751009_reps_29_hor97/#subdebate-34-0)

 -Mr Chairman, it is with great pleasure that I rise to support the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs, and in particular the bilateral aid estimates for <span class="highlight">Papua New Guinea</span>.
